children.name: wait
children.definition: /weɪt/  to spend time not doing very much, while you are expecting something to happen or expecting someone to arrive: đợi , chờ
examples: ▪ Wait here until I get back.
▪ Hurry up, everyone’s waiting.

children.name: wait for somebody
examples: ▪ I’ll stay here and wait for Suzie.

children.name: wait for something
examples: ▪ We spent almost an hour just waiting for the bus.

children.name: wait (for) a minute/two hours/a long time etc
examples: ▪ Where have you been? I’ve been waiting since 7:00.
▪ You’ll have to wait a few minutes - I’m not ready yet.

children.name: wait to do something
examples: ▪ Are you waiting to use the phone?

children.name: wait for somebody/something to do something
examples: ▪ She waited for him to reply.
▪ He waited for the applause to die down before he continued speaking.

children.name: keep somebody waitingmake someone wait, for example by arriving late
examples: ▪ I’m so sorry I kept you waiting.

children.name: wait and seewait to find out what will happen : đợi xem
examples: ▪ I’ve done as much as I can - now all I can do is wait and see what happens.

children.name: wait-and-see attitude/position/approach etc
examples: ▪ The airline industry has adopted a wait-and-see attitude to the report’s proposals.

children.name: hold on
children.definition: /hang onB1  spoken to wait, especially in a difficult situation, hoping that sth good will happen: chờ đợi ( điều gì tốt xảy ra )
examples: Captain Damas decided it was best to hold on and wait for the other ship to arrive.
We knew that if we hung on long enough, things were bound to change.
The captain decided it was best to hold on and wait for the other ship to arrive.
We hung on until the very last moment.

children.name: hang around
children.definition: / aboutUK informalto wait in one place without doing anything, so that you arewastingtime:chờ đợi ( lãng phí thời gian )
examples: ▪ Sally hung around for over an hour but no-one came.
▪ I wish we could get on with the job. I hate all this hanging about.

children.name: hang around forBritish
examples: ▪ We spent half an hour hanging about for Kerry.

children.name: hang around for hours/ages etc
examples: ▪ We were hanging around for hours before they opened the gates.

children.name: keep sb hanging around
examples: ▪ We can’t keep our troops hanging around forever, doing nothing.

children.name: stand by
children.definition: / be on standby to wait and be ready to do something if needed – used especially about soldiers, police, medical teams etc :
examples: The army are standing by.
The family stood by, knowing that she might wake up any minute.
Emergency services were on standby after someone called to say there was a bomb in the city centre.

children.name: stand by for
examples: The crew was ordered to stand by for take-off.

children.name: stand by to do sths
examples: The Foreign Minister had a helicopter standing by to whisk him to the northern city of Afula.

children.name: wait your turn
children.definition: to wait before doing sth that other people are also waiting to do, because some of them have the right to do it before you:đợi đến lượt

children.name: ▪ Everyone has to wait their turn.wait your turn to do something
examples: ▪ A long line of people waited their turn to shake his hand.

children.name: sit out
children.definition: to wait until sth has finished, especially sthunpleasantorboring:ngồi đợi cho qua
examples: ▪ If the plane’s late, there’s nothing we can do except sit it out.
▪ Tony forced himself to sit the play out.
▪ Like many people in the community, we sat out the storm at home, hoping no disasters would occur.

children.name: await
children.definition: formalto wait for sth – used about something that you know will happen or arrive :
examples: The committee is awaiting a decision from head office before it takes any action.
Two men have been charged with murder and are now in prison awaiting trial.
I will await your reply(= in a formal letter ).
In February, nearly 200,000 prisoners were awaiting trial.
The soldiers awaited the order to advance.

children.name: long-awaited
children.definition: /ˌlɒŋ əˈweɪtd◂ǁˌlɔːŋ-/  used to describe things that you have waited for for a long time:

children.name: được chờ đợi đã lâu
examples: ▪ The next morning we received the long-awaited order to attack.
▪ It is hoped that these measures will trigger the long-awaited upturn in the economy.

children.name: what you say to tell sb to wait
wait
children.definition: /weɪt/:

children.name: đợi
examples: ▪ Wait, I have a better idea.
▪ Wait! We haven’t talked to Vicky yet.

children.name: wait a minute/moment/second etc
examples: ▪ Wait a minute. I forgot to turn off the lights.
▪ Wait a second, don’t rush off!

children.name: just a moment
children.definition: just a minute/second/moment say this when you want someone to wait ashorttime:đợi 1 chút
examples: Just a minute, I’m almost ready.
Just a second, let me just check I’ve got my keys with me.

children.name: hold on
children.definition: / hang onespecially UK B1  use this to tell sb to wait for a short time: đợi chút
examples: Hold on - I haven’t finished yet.
Hold on, I'll check in my diary.
Hold on, I’ll just get my coat.

children.name: hold on a minute/moment/second etc
examples: Hang on a minute while I find her phone number.
can you hold on/hang on?
Can you hang on a minute? I just want to finish this email.

children.name: wait up
children.definition: US use this to tell sb to stop, because you want to talk to them or go with them: chờ đã
examples: Wait up, you guys! I can’t walk that fast.

children.name: bear with me
children.definition: formaluse this to ask sb to waitpatientlywhile youexplainsth or while youfinishwhat you are doing:kiên nhẫn
examples: If you’ll just bear with me, I’ll explain.
Bear with me for just a couple of minutes while I find my notes.

children.name: wait and see
children.definition: use this to tell sb to bepatientbecause they willfind outabout sth later:đợi xem

children.name: ‘So what’s this surprise you’ve got for me then?’ ‘Wait and see.’
examples: I’m not going to tell you who else I’ve invited - you’ll just have to wait and see.

children.name: see how things go U
children.definition: see how things go say this when you areadvisingsb to wait before deciding sth, in order to see how the situation develops:đợi xem thế nào đã
examples: Let’s load up the program and see how things go.
See how things go for another week, and if you’re no better we’ll change the treatment.

children.name: be right there U
children.definition: I’ll be right with you/be right there say this when you want sb to know that you will be able to see them or talk to them very soon:Tôi sẽ có mặt ngay
examples: ▪ I’m sorry for the delay, sir - I’ll be right with you.
▪ Hang your coat up and make yourself at home - I’ll be right there.

children.name: hold your horses
children.definition: say this to sb who ishurryingtoomuch, when you want them to slow down:đợi chút đã, từ từ đã
examples: Hold your horses - I haven’t even said I’ll do the job yet!

children.name: all in good time
children.definition: spokensay this to sb who wants you to hurry, to tell them that you are not going to :sẽ sớm thôi
examples: ‘When are we going to open the presents?’ ‘All in good time.’

children.name: queue
children.definition: (up) UK to stand in a line of people who are all waiting for the same thing:xếp hàng đợi
examples: ▪ Students were queuing up at the bus-stop.
queue (up) to do sth
▪ It’s worth queuing up to get the best tickets.
queue (up) for
▪ I hope we don’t have to queue for tickets
queueUK /lineUS C2 [C] a group of people, standing one behind the other, who are all waiting for the same thing:hàng người ( đứng đợi )
queue for
the front/back of the queue/line
join a queue/get in line
be in the queueUK B2 /be in (the) lineUS C2 [] to be waiting in a line with people who are all waiting for the same thing:đang đứng đợi trong hàng
While I was in the queue at the bank I met an old school friend.
Kerry started talking to the people who were in line ahead of us.
be in the queue for
Several people in the line for the rollercoaster gave up and left.
jump the queue [] UK to get sth before other people who have been waiting for it longer than you:lấn chỗ xếp hàng
My official uniform meant that we could jump the queue.
While ordinary citizens had to wait months to get hospital treatment, government officials were able to jump the queue.
The queue went right round the block.
There was a long queue for the toilets.
After waiting for an hour, we finally got to the front of the line.
I joined the queue for a taxi.
Two people tried to get in line ahead of us.

children.name: wait in line
children.definition: stand/ US to stand in a line of people who are all waiting for the same thing: đứng đợi theo hàng
examples: Go and wait in line like everyone else.

children.name: stand/wait in line for
examples: There were about 50 people standing in line for tickets outside the club.

children.name: stand/wait in line to do something
examples: People stood in line to touch him, believing his body had healing powers.

children.name: line up
children.definition: if people line up, they go and stand in a line and wait to do sth or be given sth:xếp hàng đợi
examples: The guard ordered us to line up by the wall.

children.name: line up to do sth
examples: Christopher and the other children lined up to receive their awards.

children.name: cut in
children.definition: push in/informalto join a line in front of other people who are already waiting, so that you get something before them :lấn chỗ , chen chỗ
examples: ▪ I hate people who push in in front of me!
▪ Hey, that guy just cut in line!

children.name: a period of time you have to wait
wait
children.definition: a period of time in which you wait for sth to happen, sb to arrive etc

children.name: wait for
examples: The average wait for an appointment at the clinic was eight weeks.

children.name: wait to do sth
examples: The long wait for to see the doctor really made me anxious.

children.name: have a wait
examples: They’llhave alongwait.
I’m sorry you have had such a long wait.
Relatives now face an anxious wait while the emergency services search the wreckage for survivors.

children.name: long/three-hour/two-week etc wait
examples: There was an hour wait before the next train departed.
We had a three-hour wait before we could see the doctor.

children.name: keep sb waiting
children.definition: to make sb wait, especially by arriving late:để ai phải đợi
examples: ▪ I’m sorry to keep you waiting.
▪ She was annoyed because she had been kept waiting.

children.name: keep sb waiting for
examples: ▪ Lott kept us waiting for 40 minutes while he attended another meeting.

children.name: make sb wait
children.definition: todeliberatelymake sb wait:cho đợi
examples: ▪ Shaw made us wait a few days before giving us an answer.
▪ They made me wait for half an hour before allowing me to see my father.

children.name: keep sb in suspense
children.definition: to make sb waitanxiouslyorexcitedlybefore youtellthem sth that they areeager to know:để ai hồi hộp , nóng lòng chờ đợi ( nghe điều gì )
examples: Come on - don’t keep us in suspense - who won?
The audience is kept in suspense to the very end of the play.

children.name: keep sb hanging on
children.definition: to make sb wait alongtimefor sth that you arenotactually going togivethem:để ai chờ đợi (rồi cuối cùng làm họ thất vọng )
examples: They kept me hanging on for three weeks before they finally told me they weren’t going to give me the job.

children.name: when sb is waiting for sth to happen
patient
children.definition: /ˈpeɪʃənt/  able to wait calmly without becoming annoyed or bored:kiên nhẫn
examples: ▪ I’m sure she’ll write soon. Just try to be patient.
▪ Halle was patient, waiting for the boy to finish his explanation.
You’ll just have tobe patientand wait till I’m off the phone.
patiently[adverb]B2
▪ The audience waited patiently for the show to begin.
patience[U] B2 when you can wait calmly without becoming annoyed or bored:sự kiên nhẫn
▪ It’s easy to grow your own plants - all you need is a little time and patience.
Hewaited patientlyfor Katherine to speak.

children.name: patient with
examples: Louise was very patient with me.

children.name: impatient
children.definition: /ɪmˈpeɪʃənt/  becoming annoyed because you have been waiting for a long time:mất kiên nhẫn
examples: ▪ Don’t be so impatient. I’m working as fast as I can.
▪ By this time there was a queue of impatient customers waiting to be served.
impatiently[adverb] B2
▪ The customs officer waved them on impatiently.
impatience[U] C2 annoyance caused by waiting for a long time:
▪ People were beginning to show signs of impatience.

children.name: impatient to do sth
examples: Alec strode down the street, impatient to be home.

children.name: impatient for sth
examples: The new minister was almost immediately the object of attack by politicians and press impatient for results.

children.name: impatient for somebody to do something
examples: He was eager to talk to Shildon and impatient for him to return from lunch.

children.name: get/become/grow impatient (with)
examples: ▪ I could see that Max was getting impatient with me.

children.name: look forward to
children.definition: to wait happily or excitedly for sth that is going to happen: trông chờ
examples: ▪ I’m really looking forward to this trip to Japan.
▪ We used to look forward to the weekends because that was when we could spend some time together.

children.name: look forward to doing sth
examples: ▪ I look forward to meeting you next month.

children.name: can’t wait
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt ˈweɪtǁˌkænt-/  if you say you can’t wait, you mean you feelexcitedandimpatientbecause somethinggoodis going to happen and you want it to happen as soon as possible:
examples: không thể chờ đợi
▪ We’re flying to Austria on Friday. I can’t wait!can’t wait for
▪ I can’t wait for Christmas!
▪ School is so boring. I can’t wait for the holidays to come.
can’t wait to do something
▪ I can’t wait to see their new house.
▪ She couldn’t wait to quit her job and get married.

children.name: hold your breath
children.definition: /ˌhəʊld jɔːʳ ˈbreθ/  to waitanxiouslyto see what is going to happen, especially when there is a possibility that somethingbadmay happen:

children.name: nín thở
examples: ▪ Rachel held her breath as she waited for his answer.
▪ The art world will be holding its breath to see how much these paintings sell for at auction.

children.name: expectant
children.definition: /ɪkˈspektənt/  waiting hopefully and excitedly for something to happen: trông ngóng
examples: ▪ Bright expectant faces were turned upward toward the stage.
▪ Expectant crowds waited outside the theatre.
▪ The darkened assembly room became suddenly hushed and expectant as the picture appeared on the screen.

children.name: hold on
children.definition: b)used when you have just noticed, heard, or remembered something interesting or wrong :
examples: Hold on a minute! Isn’t that your brother’s car over there?
Now hold on, Ed, that wasn't what we agreed at all!
c)used to ask someone on the telephone to wait until the person they want to talk to is available :
Can you hold on? I’ll try to find her.

children.name: hold on
children.definition: to manage to stay alive or to deal with a difficult situation:
examples: We just had to hold on until help arrived.

children.name: leave
children.definition: verbleft,leftWAIT
